articles.headline: Thrill Rides for Investors
articles.snippet: European theme parks are drawing investors, most notably from private equity funds.
articles.abstract: European theme parks are drawing investors, most notably from private equity funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLAILLY, France — Every summer as the school year ends, the tour buses start arriving, disgorging French, Spanish, German, even English children and adults at the gates of a large theme park built around the figure of Astérix, the whimsical comic book leader of the ancient Gauls.

articles.headline: Summertime. Fish Jumping. That’s Trouble.
articles.snippet: Florida’s season of “sturgeon strikes” — collisions between the leaping fish and hapless boaters  —  is under way.
articles.abstract: Florida’s season of “sturgeon strikes” — collisions between the leaping fish and hapless boaters  —  is under way.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRANFORD, Fla. — “Lots of artillery out there,” an old man hollered from the safety of the Suwannee River’s edge, and he was right. The sturgeon were jumping high and fast, twisting their armored girth in midair and returning to the depths with a stunning splash.

articles.headline: Technology Eases the Ride to Higher Tolls
articles.snippet: An economist has found that after an electronic system is put in place, tolls start rising sharply.
articles.abstract: An economist has found that after an electronic system is put in place, tolls start rising sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a stretch of the Garden State Parkway that used to feel like the tollbooth capital of America. In a span of 100 miles — from Pascack Valley, in northern New Jersey, to Barnegat, along the coast — eight different toll plazas greeted drivers. In much of the rest of the country, you wouldn’t find any tolls on a 100-mile stretch.

articles.headline: Kohlberg Kravis Plans to Go Public
articles.snippet: The firm immortalized in “Barbarians at the Gate” filed documents for an offering that would raise $1.25 billion.
articles.abstract: The firm immortalized in “Barbarians at the Gate” filed documents for an offering that would raise $1.25 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the buyout firm immortalized in “Barbarians at the Gate,” is jumping on the public offering bandwagon.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Blackstone to Buy Hilton Hotels for $26 Billion
articles.snippet: The Blackstone Group announced that it would buy Hilton Hotels for $26 billion, or $47.50 a share, a 40 percent premium over its closing price on Monday.
articles.abstract: The Blackstone Group announced that it would buy Hilton Hotels for $26 billion, or $47.50 a share, a 40 percent premium over its closing price on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group announced yesterday evening that it would buy Hilton Hotels for $26 billion, or $47.50 a share, a 40 percent premium over its closing price on Monday.

articles.headline: Republicans Trail Democrats in Fund-Raising
articles.snippet: The fund-raising totals underscored the tough political environment for Republicans candidates.
articles.abstract: The fund-raising totals underscored the tough political environment for Republicans candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, July 3 — Two more Republican presidential candidates disclosed new fund-raising totals on Tuesday that underscored the tough political environment for their party and the big money advantage that the Democrats have built.

articles.headline: In Mauritania, Seeking to End an Overfed Ideal
articles.snippet: To Mauritania’s men, fat is sexy, so women resort to force-feeding and steroid use in pursuit of obesity.
articles.abstract: To Mauritania’s men, fat is sexy, so women resort to force-feeding and steroid use in pursuit of obesity.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania — At the Olympic Sports Stadium here, a collection of dun-colored buildings rising mirage-like from the vast Sahara, about a dozen women clad in tennis shoes and sandals circled the grandstands one evening in late June, puffing with each step.

articles.headline: Say ‘Hybrid’ and Many People Will Hear ‘Prius’
articles.snippet: One reason for the success of the Toyota Prius may be that buyers want everyone to know they are driving a hybrid.
articles.abstract: One reason for the success of the Toyota Prius may be that buyers want everyone to know they are driving a hybrid.
articles.lead_paragraph: A riddle: Why has the Toyota Prius enjoyed such success, with sales of more than 400,000 in the United States, when most other hybrid models struggle to find buyers?

articles.headline: Drought Saps the Southeast, and Its Farmers
articles.snippet: The worst drought in over a century has farmers averting their gaze from a future that looks as bleak as their fields.
articles.abstract: The worst drought in over a century has farmers averting their gaze from a future that looks as bleak as their fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: TONEY, Ala., July 2 — Northern Alabama has become acre after acre of shriveled cornstalks, cracked red dirt for miles and days of unrelenting white heat. The region’s most severe drought in over a century has farmers here averting their gaze from a future that looks as bleak as their fields.

articles.headline: Detroit’s Big 3 Lost Buyers Last Month
articles.snippet: Detroit automakers’ share of the American car market fell to a record low in June, foreshadowing another summer of deep discounts, cheap car loans and deals on leases.
articles.abstract: Detroit automakers’ share of the American car market fell to a record low in June, foreshadowing another summer of deep discounts, cheap car loans and deals on leases.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, July 3 — The Detroit automakers’ share of the American car market fell to a record low in June, statistics showed Tuesday, foreshadowing another summer of deep discounts, cheap car loans and deals on leases.
